comment: I nabbed a bottle of #101, love the tropical fruit on it

For those who may not know this, Buffalo Trace did a bunch of experiments and then bottled them in 375ml bottles and are charging a fairly premium price.  The bottles all have barrel numbers on them so reviews will be for specific barrel numbers.  There's an entire singleoakproject website to talk about what this is.  Just clarifying it's not a single bottle/flavor profile - so these ratings and reviews are all going to vary widely!

#130
Very cool to try these projects & experiments from Buffalo Trace as well as other distillers.
Nose is oaky, fruity, some spice, some rye...
Palate tasty, rye, not thin
Finish, a little hot, long, pleasant
Note: Thus far all my tastes to date are at room temp and neet. No water ever added but utilized between tastes of each pour as palate cleanser.
Barrel 191. Solid pour nose was my favorite part
Bottle 187. Reminds me a little of Pappy Van Winkle. Very smooth, notes of vanilla, honey, almost a little flower.

Cracked open barrel number 52 for Memorial Day.  A fragrant nose that reminded me of a bouquet of flowers.  The initial taste was sweet.  This bourbon is smooth as a baby's behind and an easy drinker.  I give it an A for effort but honestly when I pay this much for a bourbon I expect a tad bit more of an impression.
Bold and over the top bourbon with a bottomless pit of flavor. Pairs well with over smoked meat.

Just got four bottles of this at work and was fortunate enough to try it out. By far the best bourbon I've had in a very long time. They're doing great things at Buffalo Trace.  Absolutely worth the price tag on the bottle. Bonus: each 375mL has a unique taste and is labeled according to which barrel is was batched in. A truly unique experience.

Barrel #124
Wheated bourbon with lots of sweet caramel. You get a lot of oak on the long finish. A classic wheated bourbon profile, very similar to Old Weller Antique.
Enjoyed the Barrel #84, hits of vanilla and cinnamon w a slightly oily mouth. Will be looking forward to trying some of the other releases.
Bottle #78, still havent opened it yet.
Strong of from and smooth caramel back.  Bit of orange nose, with some vanilla.  Barrel #71.
Barrel 71. High front campfire notes with smoothe taste in the finish. Notes of Carmel, vanilla, and hints of citrus ( orange peel) and sparse cinnamon.
I've tried 8, a thousand more to go
I'm particularly found of the wheaters in this collection.  They're young, but carry balance and stand on their own as unique expressions.
161 & 172 - bottles were distinctly different.  Tasted side by side.  172 is definitely better, but both were solid.  Not my favorite for the price but worth it for the novelty
Tried barrel #21. A sweeter bourbon. Reminds me of regular Buffalo Trace but a little better.
Barrel #122 – wheat, 105 entry proof, level 12 seasoning, average grain, 12 growth rings/inch, wooden ricks, #3 char, bottom half of tree
Wish I could find more. They are mostly long gone. I've got a couple. Enjoying every drop!
Love mixing the bottles together to create something "new". What a great concept and test.
Barrel 47 and it is delicious. Very smooth!
Really good stuff. Smooth. Very rare to find. Had from barrel 14
Very sweet, similar to Elmer T Lee
